title: Are the Armed Forces understood and supported by the public? British Social Attitudes towards the military and contemporary conflict.
abstractText:
Some evidence suggests that, although the public have become less supportive of the UK's military involvement in the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan, their support of the Armed Forces themselves has increased.

This study will measure:

  1. public attitudes towards (a) Service and ex-Service personnel (b) the recent conflict in Iraq and the ongoing campaign in Afghanistan
  2. the interaction between these two sets of attitudes.

Data will be collected via a new module within the 2011 British Social Attitudes Survey. The study will test the hypothesis that, although the public may support and respect the Armed Forces - even if it does not support the political objectives of the missions they undertake - this is accompanied by a lack of understanding of what Service personnel do.

It will ask whether the public has prejudicial attitudes, which lead to stigmatising beliefs regarding ex-Service personnel because of:

  • the presumed characteristics of Service life that are judged to affect the predispositions and behaviour of military personnel when they rejoin civilian society
  • negative perceptions about the military stemming from the role of the UK Armed Forces in carrying out missions which lack public support.
